code: quick_anova(   data,   group,   value,   method = c("auto", "anova", "welch", "kruskal"),   post_hoc = c("auto", "none", "tukey", "welch", "wilcox"),   conf.level = 0.95,   plot_type = c("boxplot", "violin", "both"),   add_jitter = TRUE,   point_size = 2,   point_alpha = 0.6,   show_p_value = TRUE,   p_label = c("p.format", "p.signif"),   palette = "qual_vivid",   verbose = TRUE,   ... )

title: Quick ANOVA with Automatic Method Selection ‚Äî quick_anova
text: data data frame containing variables. group Column name grouping factor. Supports quoted unquoted names via tidy evaluation. value Column name numeric response variable. method Character. One "auto" (default), "anova", "welch", "kruskal". "auto", function inspects normality homogeneity variances pick appropriate test. post_hoc Character. Post-hoc procedure: "auto" (default), "none", "tukey", "welch", "wilcox". "auto" selects Tukey ANOVA, Welch-style pairwise t-tests Welch ANOVA, pairwise Wilcoxon tests Kruskal-Wallis. conf.level Numeric. Confidence level test/intervals. Default 0.95. plot_type Character. One "boxplot", "violin", "". add_jitter Logical. Add jittered points? Default TRUE. point_size Numeric. Size jitter points. Default 2. point_alpha Numeric. Transparency jitter points (0-1). Default 0.6. show_p_value Logical. Show omnibus p-value plot? Default TRUE. p_label Character. P-value display: "p.format" (default) "p.signif" (stars). palette Character. Palette name evanverse, NULL defaults. verbose Logical. Print informative messages? Default TRUE. ... Reserved future extensions.

title: Quick ANOVA with Automatic Method Selection ‚Äî quick_anova
text: object class quick_anova_result elements: plot ggplot object comparison omnibus_result List describing main test post_hoc Post-hoc comparison table (requested) method_used Character. "anova", "welch", "kruskal" descriptive_stats Summary statistics group assumption_checks Results normality/variance checks auto_decision Details explaining automatic selections timestamp POSIXct timestamp analysis

title: Quick ANOVA with Automatic Method Selection ‚Äî quick_anova
code: set.seed(123) df <- data.frame(   group = rep(LETTERS[1:3], each = 40),   value = rnorm(120, mean = rep(c(0, 0.5, 1.2), each = 40), sd = 1) ) res <- quick_anova(df, group, value) #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Automatic Method Selection ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #> ‚Ñπ Checking normality for each group... #> ‚úî Data appears reasonably normal (using p < 0.01 threshold for medium samples). #> A: n = 40, p = 0.953 #> B: n = 40, p = 0.940 #> C: n = 40, p = 0.913 #> ‚úî Variances appear equal (Levene's test, p = 0.854) #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Omnibus Test ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #> ‚úî Completed classical one-way ANOVA (p = 0.0000) #> ‚Ñπ Applied Tukey HSD post-hoc comparisons. #> ‚úî Loaded palette "qual_vivid" ("qualitative"), 9 colors res$plot  summary(res) #>  #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Detailed Quick ANOVA Summary ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Omnibus Test  #>              Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value   Pr(>F)     #> group         2  27.51  13.755   16.91 3.53e-07 *** #> Residuals   117  95.14   0.813                      #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‚Äò***‚Äô 0.001 ‚Äò**‚Äô 0.01 ‚Äò*‚Äô 0.05 ‚Äò.‚Äô 0.1 ‚Äò ‚Äô 1 #>  #> ‚Ñπ Effect sizes: eta_squared 0.224, omega_squared 0.210 #>  #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Descriptive Statistics  #> # A tibble: 3 √ó 7 #>   group     n   mean    sd median    min   max #>   <fct> <int>  <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 A        40 0.0452 0.898 0.0906 -1.97   1.79 #> 2 B        40 0.493  0.960 0.437  -1.81   2.67 #> 3 C        40 1.21   0.844 1.15   -0.468  3.39 #>  #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Normality Checks (Shapiro-Wilk)  #> A: n = 40, p = 0.9530 #> B: n = 40, p = 0.9398 #> C: n = 40, p = 0.9129 #>  #> ‚Ñπ Decision: Medium sample size (30 <= n < 100). Data appears reasonably normal (Shapiro p >= 0.01). Using t-test. #>  #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Variance Equality (Levene)  #> Levene's test: p = 0.8542 #> Equal variance: TRUE #>  #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Post-hoc Comparisons (tukey)  #> # A tibble: 3 √ó 6 #>   group2 group1  diff     lwr   upr     `p adj` #>   <chr>  <chr>  <dbl>   <dbl> <dbl>       <dbl> #> 1 B      A      0.448 -0.0306 0.927 0.0716      #> 2 C      A      1.16   0.684  1.64  0.000000201 #> 3 C      B      0.715  0.236  1.19  0.00163     #>  #> Analysis performed: 2025-11-17 13:44:21

what: Quick Chi-Square Test with Automatic Visualization ‚Äî quick_chisq
title: Quick Chi-Square Test with Automatic Visualization ‚Äî quick_chisq
text: Perform chi-square test independence Fisher's exact test (automatically selected based expected frequencies) publication-ready visualization. Designed analyzing association two categorical variables.

title: Quick Chi-Square Test with Automatic Visualization ‚Äî quick_chisq
code: quick_chisq(   data,   var1,   var2,   method = c("auto", "chisq", "fisher", "mcnemar"),   correct = NULL,   conf.level = 0.95,   plot_type = c("bar_grouped", "bar_stacked", "heatmap"),   show_p_value = TRUE,   p_label = c("p.format", "p.signif"),   palette = "qual_vivid",   verbose = TRUE,   ... )

title: Quick Chi-Square Test with Automatic Visualization ‚Äî quick_chisq
text: data data frame containing variables. var1 Column name first categorical variable (row variable). Supports quoted unquoted names via NSE. var2 Column name second categorical variable (column variable). Supports quoted unquoted names via NSE. method Character. Test method: "auto" (default), "chisq", "fisher", "mcnemar". "auto", function intelligently selects based expected frequencies table size. WARNING: "mcnemar" paired/matched data (e.g., -measurements subjects). tests marginal homogeneity, independence. use McNemar's test independent samples - use "chisq" "fisher" instead. correct Logical NULL. Apply Yates' continuity correction? NULL (default), automatically applied 2x2 tables expected frequencies < 10. conf.level Numeric. Confidence level interval. Default 0.95. plot_type Character. Type plot: "bar_grouped" (default), "bar_stacked", "heatmap". show_p_value Logical. Display p-value plot? Default TRUE. p_label Character. P-value label format: "p.format" (numeric p-value, default) "p.signif" (stars). palette Character. Color palette name evanverse palettes. Default "qual_vivid". Set NULL use ggplot2 defaults. verbose Logical. Print diagnostic messages? Default TRUE. ... Additional arguments (currently unused, reserved future extensions).

title: Quick Chi-Square Test with Automatic Visualization ‚Äî quick_chisq

title: Quick Chi-Square Test with Automatic Visualization ‚Äî quick_chisq
text: "Quick" means easy use, simplified inaccurate. function performs full statistical testing proper assumption checking:

title: Quick Chi-Square Test with Automatic Visualization ‚Äî quick_chisq
text: function uses intelligent algorithm based expected frequencies: expected frequencies >= 5: Standard chi-square test 2x2 table expected frequency < 5: Fisher's exact test Larger table expected frequency < 5: Chi-square warning 2x2 table 5 <= expected frequency < 10: Chi-square Yates' correction

title: Quick Chi-Square Test with Automatic Visualization ‚Äî quick_chisq
text: Cramer's V calculated measure effect size: Small effect: V = 0.1 Medium effect: V = 0.3 Large effect: V = 0.5

title: Quick Chi-Square Test with Automatic Visualization ‚Äî quick_chisq
text: Pearson residuals calculated cell (observed - expected) / sqrt(expected): Values > |2| indicate significant deviation independence Values > |3| indicate significant deviation

title: Quick Chi-Square Test with Automatic Visualization ‚Äî quick_chisq
text: bar_grouped: Grouped bar chart (default) bar_stacked: Stacked bar chart (100\ heatmap: Heatmap Pearson residuals

title: Quick Chi-Square Test with Automatic Visualization ‚Äî quick_chisq
text: Categorical variables: variables must categorical coerced factors. Sample size: Fisher's exact test may computationally intensive large tables. Missing values: Automatically removed warning. Low frequencies: Cells expected frequency < 5 may lead unreliable results.

title: Quick Chi-Square Test with Automatic Visualization ‚Äî quick_chisq
code: # Example 1: Basic usage with automatic method selection set.seed(123) data <- data.frame(   treatment = sample(c("A", "B", "C"), 100, replace = TRUE),   response = sample(c("Success", "Failure"), 100, replace = TRUE,                     prob = c(0.6, 0.4)) )  result <- quick_chisq(data, var1 = treatment, var2 = response) #> ‚Ñπ treatment converted to factor with 3 levels. #> ‚Ñπ response converted to factor with 2 levels. #> ! what: Quick Correlation Analysis with Heatmap Visualization ‚Äî quick_cor
title: Quick Correlation Analysis with Heatmap Visualization ‚Äî quick_cor
text: Perform correlation analysis automatic p-value calculation publication-ready heatmap visualization. Supports multiple correlation methods significance testing optional multiple testing correction.

title: Quick Correlation Analysis with Heatmap Visualization ‚Äî quick_cor
code: quick_cor(   data,   vars = NULL,   method = c("pearson", "spearman", "kendall"),   use = "pairwise.complete.obs",   p_adjust_method = c("none", "holm", "hochberg", "hommel", "bonferroni", "BH", "BY",     "fdr"),   sig_level = c(0.001, 0.01, 0.05),   type = c("full", "upper", "lower"),   show_coef = FALSE,   show_sig = TRUE,   hc_order = TRUE,   hc_method = "complete",   palette = "gradient_rd_bu",   lab_size = 3,   title = NULL,   show_axis_x = TRUE,   show_axis_y = TRUE,   axis_x_angle = 45,   axis_y_angle = 0,   axis_text_size = 10,   verbose = TRUE,   ... )

title: Quick Correlation Analysis with Heatmap Visualization ‚Äî quick_cor
text: data data frame containing numeric variables. vars Optional character vector specifying variables include. NULL (default), numeric columns used. method Character. Correlation method: "pearson" (default), "spearman", "kendall". use Character. Method handling missing values, passed cor(). Default "pairwise.complete.obs". options: "everything", ".obs", "complete.obs", "na..complete". p_adjust_method Character. Method p-value adjustment multiple testing. Default "none". Options: "holm", "hochberg", "hommel", "bonferroni", "BH", "", "fdr", "none". See p.adjust. sig_level Numeric vector. Significance levels star annotations. Default c(0.001, 0.01, 0.05) corresponding ***, **, *. type Character. Type heatmap: "full" (default), "upper", "lower". show_coef Logical. Display correlation coefficients heatmap? Default FALSE. show_sig Logical. Display significance stars heatmap? Default TRUE. hc_order Logical. Reorder variables using hierarchical clustering? Default TRUE. hc_method Character. Hierarchical clustering method hc_order = TRUE. Default "complete". See hclust. palette Character. Color palette name evanverse palettes. Default "gradient_rd_bu" (diverging Red-Blue palette, recommended correlation matrices). Set NULL use ggplot2 defaults. diverging options: "piyg", "earthy_diverge", "fire_ice_duo". lab_size Numeric. Size coefficient labels show_coef = TRUE. Default 3. title Character. Plot title. Default NULL (title). show_axis_x Logical. Display x-axis labels? Default TRUE. show_axis_y Logical. Display y-axis labels? Default TRUE. axis_x_angle Numeric. Rotation angle x-axis labels degrees. Default 45. Common values: 0 (horizontal), 45 (diagonal), 90 (vertical). axis_y_angle Numeric. Rotation angle y-axis labels degrees. Default 0 (horizontal). axis_text_size Numeric. Font size axis labels. Default 10. verbose Logical. Print diagnostic messages? Default TRUE. ... Additional arguments (currently unused, reserved future extensions).

title: Quick Correlation Analysis with Heatmap Visualization ‚Äî quick_cor
text: object class quick_cor_result containing: plot ggplot object correlation heatmap cor_matrix Correlation coefficient matrix p_matrix P-value matrix (unadjusted) p_adjusted Adjusted p-value matrix (p_adjust_method != "none") method_used Correlation method used significant_pairs Data frame significant correlation pairs descriptive_stats Descriptive statistics variable parameters List analysis parameters timestamp POSIXct timestamp analysis

title: Quick Correlation Analysis with Heatmap Visualization ‚Äî quick_cor
text: "Quick" means easy use, simplified inaccurate. function performs complete correlation analysis proper statistical testing:

title: Quick Correlation Analysis with Heatmap Visualization ‚Äî quick_cor
text: Pearson: Measures linear relationships, assumes normality Spearman: Rank-based, robust outliers non-normality Kendall: Rank-based, better small samples many ties

title: Quick Correlation Analysis with Heatmap Visualization ‚Äî quick_cor
text: P-values calculated pairwise correlation. function automatically uses psych::corr.test() psych package installed, provides significantly faster computation (10-100x speedup large matrices) compared base R stats::cor.test() loop. psych available, function gracefully falls back base R implementation. large correlation matrices many tests, consider using p_adjust_method control multiple testing (e.g., "bonferroni" "fdr"). Performance tip: Install psych package faster p-value computation: install.packages("psych")

title: Quick Correlation Analysis with Heatmap Visualization ‚Äî quick_cor
text: heatmap includes: Color-coded correlation coefficients (red = positive, blue = negative) Optional significance stars (***, **, *) Optional coefficient values Hierarchical clustering group similar variables Publication-ready styling

title: Quick Correlation Analysis with Heatmap Visualization ‚Äî quick_cor
text: Numeric variables : function automatically selects numeric columns uses variables specified vars. Constant variables: Variables zero variance automatically removed warning. Sample size: function warn sample sizes small (n < 5) removing missing values. Missing values: Handled according use parameter. "pairwise.complete.obs" recommended optimal sample size usage. Optional dependencies: optimal performance, install psych (fast p-value computation) ggcorrplot (heatmap visualization). function work without may slower use fallback plotting.

what: Quick t-test with Automatic Visualization ‚Äî quick_ttest
title: Quick t-test with Automatic Visualization ‚Äî quick_ttest
text: Perform t-test Wilcoxon test (automatically selected based data characteristics sample size) publication-ready visualization. Designed comparing two groups .

title: Quick t-test with Automatic Visualization ‚Äî quick_ttest
code: quick_ttest(   data,   group,   value,   method = c("auto", "t.test", "wilcox.test"),   paired = FALSE,   id,   alternative = c("two.sided", "less", "greater"),   var.equal = NULL,   conf.level = 0.95,   plot_type = c("boxplot", "violin", "both"),   add_jitter = TRUE,   point_size = 2,   point_alpha = 0.6,   show_p_value = TRUE,   p_label = c("p.signif", "p.format"),   palette = "qual_vivid",   verbose = TRUE,   ... )

title: Quick t-test with Automatic Visualization ‚Äî quick_ttest
text: data data frame containing variables. group Column name grouping variable (must exactly 2 levels). Supports quoted unquoted names via NSE. value Column name numeric values compare. Supports quoted unquoted names via NSE. method Character. Test method: "auto" (default), "t.test", "wilcox.test". "auto", function intelligently selects based normality sample size. paired Logical. Whether perform paired test. Default FALSE. TRUE, id parameter must specified match pairs. id Column name pairing ID variable (required paired = TRUE). unique ID appear exactly group. Supports quoted unquoted names via NSE. alternative Character. Alternative hypothesis: "two.sided" (default), "less", "greater". var.equal Logical NULL. Assume equal variances? NULL (default), automatically tested using Levene's test (ignored paired tests). conf.level Numeric. Confidence level interval. Default 0.95. plot_type Character. Type plot: "boxplot" (default), "violin", "". add_jitter Logical. Add jittered points plot? Default TRUE. point_size Numeric. Size points. Default 2. point_alpha Numeric. Transparency points (0-1). Default 0.6. show_p_value Logical. Display p-value plot? Default TRUE. p_label Character. P-value label format: "p.signif" (stars, default) "p.format" (numeric p-value). palette Character. Color palette name evanverse palettes. Default "qual_vivid". Set NULL use ggplot2 defaults. verbose Logical. Print diagnostic messages? Default TRUE. ... Additional arguments (currently unused, reserved future extensions).

title: Quick t-test with Automatic Visualization ‚Äî quick_ttest
text: object class quick_ttest_result containing: plot ggplot object comparison visualization test_result htest object t.test() wilcox.test() method_used Character string test method used normality_tests List Shapiro-Wilk test results group variance_test Levene's test result (applicable) descriptive_stats Data frame descriptive statistics group auto_decision Details automatic method selection timestamp POSIXct timestamp analysis

title: Quick t-test with Automatic Visualization ‚Äî quick_ttest
text: "Quick" means easy use, simplified inaccurate. function performs full statistical testing proper assumption checking:

title: Quick t-test with Automatic Visualization ‚Äî quick_ttest
text: function uses intelligent algorithm considers normality sample size: Large samples (n ‚â• 100 per group): Prefers t-test due Central Limit Theorem, even Shapiro-Wilk rejects normality (becomes overly sensitive large samples). Medium samples (30 ‚â§ n < 100): Uses Shapiro-Wilk test stricter threshold (p < 0.01) avoid false positives. Small samples (n < 30): Strictly checks normality standard threshold (p < 0.05). approach avoids common pitfall automatically switching non-parametric tests large samples t-test actually appropriate.

title: Quick t-test with Automatic Visualization ‚Äî quick_ttest
text: var.equal = NULL t-test selected, Levene's test performed. variances unequal (p < 0.05), Welch's t-test used automatically.

title: Quick t-test with Automatic Visualization ‚Äî quick_ttest
text: plot includes: Boxplot, violin plot, (based plot_type) Individual data points (add_jitter = TRUE) Statistical comparison p-value Publication-ready styling

title: Quick t-test with Automatic Visualization ‚Äî quick_ttest
text: Two groups : function requires exactly 2 levels grouping variable. Sample size warnings: function warn sample sizes small (< 5) highly unbalanced (ratio > 3:1). Missing values: Automatically removed warning.

title: Quick t-test with Automatic Visualization ‚Äî quick_ttest
code: # Example 1: Basic usage with automatic method selection set.seed(123) data <- data.frame(   group = rep(c("Control", "Treatment"), each = 30),   expression = c(rnorm(30, mean = 5), rnorm(30, mean = 6)) )  result <- quick_ttest(data, group = group, value = expression) #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Automatic Method Selection ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #> ‚Ñπ Checking normality for each group... #> ‚úî Data appears reasonably normal (using p < 0.01 threshold for medium samples). #> Control: n = 30, p = 0.797 #> Treatment: n = 30, p = 0.961 #> ‚úî Variances appear equal (Levene's test, p = 0.304) #> ‚úî Using Student's t-test (equal variances assumed) #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Statistical Test ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #> ‚úî Significant difference detected (p < 0.001) #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Creating Visualization ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #> ‚úî Loaded palette "qual_vivid" ("qualitative"), 9 colors #> ‚úî Analysis complete! print(result)  #>  #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Quick t-test Results ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #>  #> ‚Ñπ Method: t.test #> ‚úî Significant difference (p < 0.001) #>  #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Descriptive Statistics  #> # A tibble: 2 √ó 7 #>   group         n  mean    sd median   min   max #>   <fct>     <int> <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 Control      30  4.95 0.981   4.93  3.03  6.79 #> 2 Treatment    30  6.18 0.835   6.05  4.45  8.17 #>  #> Use `summary()` for detailed results.  # Example 2: Paired samples (e.g., before/after) paired_data <- data.frame(   patient = rep(1:20, 2),   timepoint = rep(c("Before", "After"), each = 20),   score = c(rnorm(20, 50, 10), rnorm(20, 55, 10)) )  result <- quick_ttest(paired_data,                       group = timepoint,                       value = score,                       paired = TRUE,                       id = patient) #> ‚úî Validated 20 paired observations. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Automatic Method Selection ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #> ‚Ñπ Checking normality of paired differences... #> ‚úî Differences appear normal (Shapiro-Wilk p >= 0.05). #> Differences: n = 20, p = 0.351 #> ‚úî Using paired t-test #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Statistical Test ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #> ‚úî Significant difference detected (p = 0.0048) #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Creating Visualization ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #> ‚úî Loaded palette "qual_vivid" ("qualitative"), 9 colors #> ‚úî Analysis complete!  # Example 3: Non-normal data with manual method selection skewed_data <- data.frame(   group = rep(c("A", "B"), each = 25),   value = c(rexp(25, rate = 0.5), rexp(25, rate = 1)) )  result <- quick_ttest(skewed_data,                       group = group,                       value = value,                       method = "wilcox.test",                       verbose = TRUE) #> ‚Ñπ Using manually specified method: wilcox.test #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Statistical Test ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #> ‚úî Significant difference detected (p = 0.0052) #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Creating Visualization ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #> ‚úî Loaded palette "qual_vivid" ("qualitative"), 9 colors #> ‚úî Analysis complete!  # Example 4: Customize visualization result <- quick_ttest(data,                       group = group,                       value = expression,                       plot_type = "both",                       palette = "qual_balanced",                       p_label = "p.format") #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Automatic Method Selection ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #> ‚Ñπ Checking normality for each group... #> ‚úî Data appears reasonably normal (using p < 0.01 threshold for medium samples). #> Control: n = 30, p = 0.797 #> Treatment: n = 30, p = 0.961 #> ‚úî Variances appear equal (Levene's test, p = 0.304) #> ‚úî Using Student's t-test (equal variances assumed) #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Statistical Test ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #> ‚úî Significant difference detected (p < 0.001) #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Creating Visualization ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #> ‚úî Loaded palette "qual_balanced" ("qualitative"), 4 colors #> ‚úî Analysis complete!  # Access components result$plot              # ggplot object  result$test_result       # htest object #>  #> 	Two Sample t-test #>  #> data:  value by group #> t = -5.2098, df = 58, p-value = 2.616e-06 #> alternative hypothesis: true difference in means between group Control and group Treatment is not equal to 0 #> 95 percent confidence interval: #>  -1.6962870 -0.7545972 #> sample estimates: #>   mean in group Control mean in group Treatment  #>                4.952896                6.178338  #>  summary(result)          # Detailed summary #>  #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Detailed Quick t-test Summary ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Test Method  #> Method used: t.test #> Paired: FALSE #> Alternative: two.sided #> Equal variance: TRUE #>  #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Test Result  #>  #> 	Two Sample t-test #>  #> data:  value by group #> t = -5.2098, df = 58, p-value = 2.616e-06 #> alternative hypothesis: true difference in means between group Control and group Treatment is not equal to 0 #> 95 percent confidence interval: #>  -1.6962870 -0.7545972 #> sample estimates: #>   mean in group Control mean in group Treatment  #>                4.952896                6.178338  #>  #>  #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Descriptive Statistics  #> # A tibble: 2 √ó 7 #>   group         n  mean    sd median   min   max #>   <fct>     <int> <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 Control      30  4.95 0.981   4.93  3.03  6.79 #> 2 Treatment    30  6.18 0.835   6.05  4.45  8.17 #>  #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Normality Tests (Shapiro-Wilk)  #> Control: n = 30, p = 0.7966 #> Treatment: n = 30, p = 0.9614 #>  #> ‚Ñπ Decision: Medium sample size (30 <= n < 100). Data appears reasonably normal (Shapiro p >= 0.01). Using t-test. #>  #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Variance Equality Test (Levene)  #> Levene's test: p = 0.3038 #> Equal variances: TRUE #>  #> Analysis performed: 2025-11-17 13:44:26

title: Flexible Excel reader ‚Äî read_excel_flex
text: file_path Path Excel file (.xlsx .xls). sheet Sheet name index read (default: 1). skip Number lines skip reading data (default: 0). header Logical. Whether first row contains column names (default: TRUE). range Optional cell range (e.g., "B2:D100"). Default: NULL. col_types Optional vector specifying column types; passed readxl. clean_names Logical. Clean column names janitor::clean_names() (default: TRUE). guess_max Max rows guess column types (default: 1000). trim_ws Logical. Trim surrounding whitespace text fields (default: TRUE). na Values interpret NA (default: ""). verbose Logical. Show CLI output (default: TRUE).

Supports `sheet =`, `range =`, etc. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ droplevels  #> `droplevels(df)` removes unused factor levels from a data frame or factor. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ modifyList  #> `modifyList(x, y)` merges two lists; elements in `y` overwrite those in `x`. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ do.call  #> `do.call(fun, args)` calls a function with arguments in a list: `do.call(plot, list(x = 1:10))`. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ sprintf  #> `sprintf("Hello, %s!", name)` formats strings with `%s`, `%d`, etc. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ scRNAseq  #> `scRNAseq` (Bioconductor) provides scRNA-seq datasets, e.g., `ZeiselBrainData()`. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ basename  #> `basename(path)` extracts the filename from a full path. See also `dirname()`. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ here  #> `here::here("data", "raw", "sample1.rds")` builds a path from project root. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ stopifnot  #> `stopifnot(cond1, cond2, ...)` throws if any condition is FALSE. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ object.size  #> `object.size(x)` estimates memory size; use `format()` to pretty-print. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ slice  #> `slice(df, 1:3)` selects rows by position; see `slice_head()`, `slice_tail()`, `slice_max()`. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ unzip  #> `unzip("file.zip", exdir = "dir")` extracts ZIP archives. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ gunzip  #> `R.utils::gunzip("file.csv.gz", remove = FALSE)` decompresses .gz files. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ untar  #> `untar("file.tar.gz", exdir = "dir")` extracts .tar or .tar.gz archives. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ NoLegend  #> `NoLegend()` removes legends from ggplot2/Seurat plots. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ RotatedAxis  #> `RotatedAxis()` rotates x-axis text for readability in dot plots. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ guides  #> `guides(fill = "none")` customizes or removes legends (with `scale_*`). #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ log2  #> `log2(x)` base-2 logarithm (often for fold change). #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ log  #> `log(x, base = exp(1))` natural log by default; set `base = 10` or `2` for others. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ log10  #> `log10(x)` base-10 logarithm (orders of magnitude). #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ round  #> `round(x, digits = 0)` rounds; use `signif()` for significant digits. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ floor  #> `floor(x)` greatest integer <= x (e.g., `floor(2.8)` -> 2). #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ ceiling  #> `ceiling(x)` smallest integer >= x (e.g., `ceiling(2.1)` -> 3). #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ cut  #> `cut(x, breaks)` bins numeric vector; `breaks = 3` or custom; `labels = FALSE` for group indices. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ cumsum  #> `cumsum(x)` cumulative sum. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ cumprod  #> `cumprod(x)` cumulative product. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ cummin  #> `cummin(x)` running minimum. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ cummax  #> `cummax(x)` running maximum. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ row_number  #> `row_number(x)` order rank (ties broken arbitrarily). #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ min_rank  #> `min_rank(x)` ties get the same minimum rank. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ dense_rank  #> `dense_rank(x)` like `min_rank()` but without gaps. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ percent_rank  #> `percent_rank(x)` relative rank in [0,1], normalized by n-1. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ cume_dist  #> `cume_dist(x)` cumulative proportion of values <= x. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ str_view  #> `stringr::str_view(string, pattern)` highlights regex matches; `str_view_all()` for all. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ str_c  #> `stringr::str_c(...)` concatenates; use `sep`/`collapse` as needed. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ str_glue  #> `glue::glue("Hello, {name}!")` inline expressions with `{}`. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ str_flatten  #> `stringr::str_flatten(x, collapse = ", ")` join a character vector. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ str_length  #> `stringr::str_length(x)` string lengths. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ str_sub  #> `stringr::str_sub(x, start, end)` extract/replace substrings (supports negative indices). #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ today  #> `lubridate::today()` current Date (no time). #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ now  #> `lubridate::now()` current POSIXct date-time. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Sys.timezone  #> `Sys.timezone()` system time zone name. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ skimr  #> `skimr::skim(df)` compact, readable data summaries. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ par  #> `par(mfrow = c(m, n))` split plotting area (e.g., 2x2). #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ layout  #> `layout(matrix, widths, heights)` flexible plot arrangement. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ datatable  #> `DT::datatable(data)` interactive table (search/filter/sort/paginate). #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ windowsFonts  #> `windowsFonts()` register system fonts (Windows). #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ sign  #> `sign(x)` returns -1/0/1 for negative/zero/positive. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ reactable  #> `reactable::reactable(data)` modern interactive table. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ trimws  #> `trimws(x)` removes leading and trailing whitespace. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ cranlogs  #> `cranlogs::cran_downloads('pkgname', from = 'last-month')` gets CRAN download stats; use `'last-week'`, `'last-day'`, or specific dates. #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ dlstats  #> `dlstats::cran_stats('pkgname')` shows CRAN download trends with plots; supports Bioconductor via `source = 'bioc'`. #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Available Keywords ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ #> `glimpse, read_excel, droplevels, modifyList, do.call, sprintf, scRNAseq, #> basename, here, stopifnot, object.size, slice, unzip, gunzip, untar, NoLegend, #> RotatedAxis, guides, log2, log, log10, round, floor, ceiling, cut, cumsum, #> cumprod, cummin, cummax, row_number, min_rank, dense_rank, percent_rank, #> cume_dist, str_view, str_c, str_glue, str_flatten, str_length, str_sub, today, #> now, Sys.timezone, skimr, par, layout, datatable, windowsFonts, sign, #> reactable, trimws, cranlogs, dlstats`

title: Discrete Color and Fill Scales for evanverse Palettes ‚Äî scale_evanverse
text: ggplot2 scale object can added ggplot.

title: Discrete Color and Fill Scales for evanverse Palettes ‚Äî scale_evanverse
text: scale_color_evanverse() scale_fill_evanverse() functions automatically: Infer palette type naming convention (seq_, div_, qual_) Handle color interpolation intelligently based palette type: Qualitative palettes: Direct color selection (interpolation) Sequential/Diverging palettes: Smooth interpolation n < palette size Support standard ggplot2 scale parameters Provide informative error messages warnings

title: Discrete Color and Fill Scales for evanverse Palettes ‚Äî scale_evanverse
code: library(ggplot2)  # Basic usage with automatic type inference ggplot(iris, aes(Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width, color = Species)) +   geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.8) +   scale_color_evanverse("qual_vivid") +   theme_minimal()   # Fill scale for boxplots ggplot(iris, aes(x = Species, y = Sepal.Length, fill = Species)) +   geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.7) +   scale_fill_evanverse("qual_vivid") +   theme_minimal()   # Reverse color order ggplot(iris, aes(Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width, color = Species)) +   geom_point(size = 3) +   scale_color_evanverse("qual_vivid", reverse = TRUE) +   theme_minimal()   # Explicitly specify type ggplot(iris, aes(Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width, color = Species)) +   geom_point(size = 3) +   scale_color_evanverse("qual_vivid", type = "qualitative") +   theme_minimal()   # Limit number of colors ggplot(iris, aes(Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width, color = Species)) +   geom_point(size = 3) +   scale_color_evanverse("qual_vivid", n = 3) +   theme_minimal()   # Custom legend name and labels ggplot(iris, aes(Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width, color = Species)) +   geom_point(size = 3) +   scale_color_evanverse(     "qual_vivid",     name = "Iris Species",     labels = c("Setosa", "Versicolor", "Virginica")   ) +   theme_minimal()   # Bar plot with fill ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = factor(cyl), fill = factor(cyl))) +   geom_bar() +   scale_fill_evanverse("qual_vibrant") +   labs(x = "Cylinders", y = "Count", fill = "Cylinders") +   theme_minimal()

title: Calculate Statistical Power ‚Äî stat_power
text: Compute statistical power (probability correctly rejecting null hypothesis) given sample size, effect size, significance level. Supports multiple test types including t-tests, ANOVA, proportion tests, correlation tests, chi-square tests.

title: Calculate Statistical Power ‚Äî stat_power
code: stat_power(   n,   effect_size,   test = c("t.test", "anova", "proportion", "correlation", "chisq"),   type = c("two.sample", "one.sample", "paired"),   alternative = c("two.sided", "less", "greater"),   alpha = 0.05,   k = NULL,   df = NULL,   plot = TRUE,   plot_range = NULL,   palette = "qual_vivid",   verbose = TRUE )

title: Calculate Statistical Power ‚Äî stat_power
text: n Integer. Sample size. Interpretation depends test type: t-tests ANOVA: Sample size per group Proportion test: Total sample size (one-sample test) Correlation: Total number paired observations Chi-square: Total sample size effect_size Numeric. Effect size appropriate test (must positive): Cohen's d t-tests (small: 0.2, medium: 0.5, large: 0.8) Cohen's f ANOVA (small: 0.1, medium: 0.25, large: 0.4) Cohen's h proportion tests (small: 0.2, medium: 0.5, large: 0.8) Correlation coefficient r correlation tests (small: 0.1, medium: 0.3, large: 0.5). Use absolute value; power positive negative correlations. Cohen's w chi-square tests (small: 0.1, medium: 0.3, large: 0.5) test Character. Type statistical test: "t.test" (default), "anova", "proportion", "correlation", "chisq". type Character. t-tests : "two.sample" (default), "one.sample", "paired". alternative Character. Direction alternative hypothesis: "two.sided" (default), "less", "greater". Note: applicable t-tests, proportion tests, correlation tests. Ignored ANOVA chi-square tests (inherently non-directional). alpha Numeric. Significance level (Type error rate). Default: 0.05. k Integer. Number groups (required ANOVA). df Integer. Degrees freedom (required chi-square tests). plot Logical. Generate power curve plot? Default: TRUE. plot_range Numeric vector length 2. Range sample sizes power curve. NULL (default), automatically determined. palette Character. evanverse palette name plot. Default: "qual_vivid". verbose Logical. Print detailed diagnostic information? Default: TRUE.

title: Calculate Statistical Power ‚Äî stat_power
text: object class stat_power_result containing: power calculated statistical power (probability detecting effect) n Sample size used calculation effect_size Effect size used calculation alpha Significance level test_type Type statistical test test_subtype Subtype t-tests (e.g., "two.sample", "one.sample", "paired"); NULL tests alternative Direction alternative hypothesis used test k Number groups (ANOVA); NULL tests df Degrees freedom (chi-square tests); NULL tests plot ggplot2 object showing power curve (plot = TRUE); NULL otherwise pwr_object Raw result object pwr package function details List interpretation recommendation text timestamp POSIXct timestamp calculation performed

title: Calculate Statistical Power ‚Äî stat_power
text: Statistical power probability correctly rejecting null hypothesis false (.e., detecting true effect). Conventionally, power 0.8 (80%) considered adequate, though higher power (0.9 0.95) may desirable contexts. function uses pwr package power calculations, ensuring accurate results based well-established statistical theory.

title: Calculate Statistical Power ‚Äî stat_power
text: Proportion Test: Uses pwr.p.test, one-sample proportion tests (testing single proportion hypothesized value). two-sample proportion tests, consider using specialized tools packages. effect_size parameter uses Cohen's h, quantifies difference two proportions. one-sample settings, Cohen's h computed observed proportion p null hypothesis proportion p0.

title: Calculate Statistical Power ‚Äî stat_power
text: plot = TRUE, power curve generated showing statistical power changes sample size. curve helps visualize: current power level (marked red point) conventional 0.8 power threshold (red dashed line) increasing sample size affects power

title: Calculate Statistical Power ‚Äî stat_power
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Example 1: Power for a two-sample t-test result <- stat_power(   n = 30,   effect_size = 0.5,   test = "t.test",   type = "two.sample" ) print(result) plot(result)  # Example 2: Power for ANOVA with 3 groups stat_power(   n = 25,   effect_size = 0.25,   test = "anova",   k = 3 )  # Example 3: Power for correlation test stat_power(   n = 50,   effect_size = 0.3,   test = "correlation" ) } # }

title: Void Value Utilities ‚Äî void
code: is_void(c(NA, "", "text"))                  # TRUE TRUE FALSE #> [1]  TRUE  TRUE FALSE is_void(list(NA, "", NULL, "a"))            # TRUE TRUE TRUE FALSE #> [1]  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE FALSE is_void("NA", include_na = FALSE)           # FALSE #> [1] FALSE is_void(NULL)                               # TRUE #> [1] TRUE any_void(c("a", "", NA))                # TRUE #> [1] TRUE any_void(list("x", NULL, "y"))          # TRUE #> [1] TRUE any_void(c("a", "b", "c"))              # FALSE #> [1] FALSE any_void(NULL)                          # TRUE #> [1] TRUE any_void("", include_empty_str = FALSE) # FALSE #> [1] FALSE drop_void(c("apple", "", NA, "banana")) #> [1] "apple"  "banana" drop_void(list("A", NA, "", NULL, "B")) #> [[1]] #> [1] "A" #>  #> [[2]] #> [1] "B" #>  drop_void(c("", NA), include_na = FALSE) #> [1] NA replace_void(c(NA, "", "a"), value = "N/A") #> [1] "N/A" "N/A" "a"   replace_void(list("A", "", NULL, NA), value = "missing") #> [[1]] #> [1] "A" #>  #> [[2]] #> [1] "missing" #>  #> [[3]] #> [1] "missing" #>  #> [[4]] #> [1] "missing" #>  replace_void(c("", "b"), value = 0, include_empty_str = TRUE) #> [1] "0" "b" df <- data.frame(name = c("A", "", "C"), score = c(1, NA, 3), id = 1:3) cols_with_void(df) #> [1] "name"  "score" cols_with_void(df, return_names = FALSE) #>  name score    id  #>  TRUE  TRUE FALSE  cols_with_void(df, include_na = FALSE) #> [1] "name" df <- data.frame(id = 1:3, name = c("A", "", "C"), score = c(10, NA, 20)) rows_with_void(df) #> [1] FALSE  TRUE FALSE df[rows_with_void(df), ] #>   id name score #> 2  2         NA

Default: TRUE. open_after Whether open file writing (platform-dependent). Default: FALSE. verbose Whether print CLI messages (info/warn/success). Errors always shown. Default: TRUE.

text: users upgrading 0.3.6:
code: # OLD (0.3.6) - No longer works in 0.3.7 create_palette("my_palette", "sequential", colors)  # NEW (0.3.7) - Explicit path required temp_dir <- file.path(tempdir(), "palettes") create_palette("my_palette", "sequential", colors, color_dir = temp_dir)  # For production use, specify your desired directory create_palette("my_palette", "sequential", colors,                color_dir = "path/to/your/palette/directory")

title: evanverse 0.3.0
text: plot_forest() ‚Äî Forest plots publication-style defaults (forestploter), significance bolding, color recycling, alignment options. plot_bar() ‚Äî Bar charts optional fill grouping, sorting, vertical/horizontal layout, clean defaults. read_excel_flex() ‚Äî Enhanced Excel reader (readxl) optional name cleaning (janitor), range/col_types controls, CLI feedback. write_xlsx_flex() ‚Äî Flexible Excel writer (openxlsx) header styling, auto column width, overwrite/timestamp options. view() ‚Äî Quick interactive data viewer (reactable) exploration/QC. set_mirror() ‚Äî Switch CRAN/Bioconductor mirrors predefined, named endpoints. pkg_functions() ‚Äî List exported functions installed package, optional keyword filtering.

title: evanverse 0.3.0
text: Inlined, robust delimiter detection .csv/.tsv/.txt .gz files Stricter parameter checks clearer CLI error messages Enhanced encoding guardrails better file handling Source normalization via strict match() function Supports ‚ÄúCRAN‚Äù, ‚ÄúGitHub‚Äù, ‚ÄúBioconductor‚Äù sources Clearer messages mirror handling aligned set_mirror() robust CRAN/Bioconductor database retrieval Helpful suggestions GitHub package installations Optional preview printing clearer CLI output %% %near% messages standardized (emoji) Tighter type/shape checks cleaner examples %nin% implemented Negate(%%) simple, predictable NA semantics map_column() uses unified cli output counts unmatched keys Skips numeric columns design, removes emoji, adds modular separators with_timer() simplified using tictoc timing cli output remind() rendering fixed cli braces partial/case-insensitive matches rgb2hex() input validation tightened concise CLI feedback rows_with_void() header streamlined, delegates detection is_void() .onAttach switched plain cli::cli_text() messages (emoji), CRAN-safe Roxygen examples trimmed non-interactive/CRAN environments Consistent headers separators throughout documentation
